I’ve no idea what’s got all these creatures so angry, but I think you are going to need to kill a decent number to drive them away!
As another creature falls, the remaining beasts turn tail and flee, and the forest is silent again. You wonder if it is permanent.
Well, the job is done. Hopefully they won’t return.
I would quite like it if Deep Terrors stayed in the deep, DEEP sea!
I’m considering filling in the sewers under Demonsgate...
We have plumbing!? I always went outside…
...We’ll discuss that later.
This seems just like the situation at Sweetwater.
With these Inox, though, it might just be a fair fight. As long as we don’t go near the sewers.
Take back this settlement. You know what to do.
The last Deep Terror recedes back into the sewer in pain, and the Inox shout their victory. They commend your bravery.
Kailej’s chieftain says the river’s source is at Crystal Hollow, up in the mountains.
If we promise to destroy the birthplace of this Rot, he’ll stop anything following us there. Sound good?
There’s the last artillery emplacement!
We cannot allow the Council’s work to fail. Kill them!
Oi, someone order some crushed bugs?
There’s your reinforcements. Now push to the Council!
Those are the doors to the City Hall. Push through!
Yes, just battle that Stone Golem as well as all these friendly Militia soldiers. Easy.
There’s just a few Harrowers here!? This council actually was bug-brained…
Why do you fight the Council of Shadow? We are bettering you all!
Clear out this hive. I fear there is more to this.
You’ve been discovered, but no matter. You need to destroy this artillery.
Let’s just hope this is all the Militia will throw at you… I’ve seen enough Stone Golems for a lifetime.
Either way, you wouldn’t be the one fighting them.
Yes, but they’re scary!
The last Harrower dies, and an uneasy silence falls over the scenes of carnage around Keyport.
It is quickly interrupted by a banging from inside the City Hall. Investigating, you find the Keyport Elders, tied up inside their office.
The Keyport Council told me that Harrowers from The Council of Shadow came from Staybright Fort, and placed their own soldiers into Keyport’s City Guard.
The Council of Shadow, eh? That name is even worse.
Whoever they are, we’ll have to dig them out.
At the Start of each round, the Earth Element is set to Strong
You find the source of the power, a number of ancient stones which the Imps and Vermling Shaman are using in a ritual.
This will surely end very badly for Lowtown if you don’t drive the Imps away.
Earth Magic is strong here, and will always be available at the start of the turn. Use this to your advantage!
As the last enemy falls, the pressure in the air immediately abates, the light returns to normal. and the insects of the forest start up again. Your work here is done.
There’s the Artillery! Give it all you’ve got, and get out of there!
Protect this equipment with your lives, men! The Council demands it!
All this equipment… Why would Keyport put this much money into military ordnance outside its own walls?
The artillery should be deeper in town. You’ll have to fight your way to it.
Without the Artillery, the Militia should lose morale and retreat!
You escape with your lives, leaving the artillery a pile of scrap in your wake.
Good job. Without that artillery, it looks like the troops in Millpond are pulling back. The town will be free again.
Won’t Keyport’s defenses be a little more… prickly? They’ll be protecting their damn council, after all.
There is no way we can get through defenses like that into Keyport. We’re going to need more troops, and I might know just where to find them...
The clearing outside the cairns has Demons waiting for you... but there are no Savvas.
There are two chambers to explore. You may need to split up if you want to complete the dungeon quickly enough.
Yes, it looks like there may be crystals in both directions.
With the Altars destroyed and Savvas defeated, any remaining Demons dissipate.
Once the two sites are cleansed, the Savvas will be badly weakened.
Focus on those Demon Altars - a lack of Demons will make mopping up the Cultists easier!
After that, the door ahead looks like a shortcut out.
Oh... Not really a shortcut.
Nope. Just Militia and… wait, what is that? A floating cloak?
You are a fool for resisting the Council and their gifts!
It’s a Harrower, what's that doing here?
These Cultists have been proving to be a real problem for the town.
I was wondering how people running around in bathrobes were such a nuisance… but the Demons explain it.
Clear them out, and the mayor will agree to fight with us.
As the Harrower is slain, its body disintegrates into a cloud of insects.
I haven’t seen many Harrowers this deep in human territory...
It seemed to be working for that dodgy council… talk about corrupted politicians.
Whatever it was doing here, it spooked the mayor into providing supplies and safe routes to help us attack Keyport.
All Enemies start Disarmed
Looks like you’ve taken this detachment of archers by surprise, do as much damage as you can before they regroup.
You’ll need to kill enough of them to break the siege. Charge!!
Phew, that was a major battle, but the siege on the Bridge is now lifted. We’re almost at the coast!
I don’t think there’s anything you could do to get me within ten feet of a Lurker, let alone work with one...
Inox and Lurkers working together? This is worrying.
Well, I suppose we should save these nomads so they can pay u- er, help us solve this mystery of course!
With the last Inox’s blood soaking into the sand, the nomads approach you with thanks and information.
They say the Lurkers made a deal with the Inox: help them recover the teeth from the nomads, and they won’t attack Kailej.
Looks like the teeth are now ours, but the attack on Kailej was never called off.
Night Demons? Really?
I wonder how the Rot is spawning Demons… It might even be able to spawn a-
No.
Was that some kind of... ritual?
Somehow, there’s something even more insane than Cultists?. I hate this job. Oh, why does it have to pay so well?
No one’s going to pay us anything until we put a stop to the Rot. Push through!
With the dungeon cleared of threats, you’re now able to search it.
It appears that the Lurkers and Deep Terrors were indeed performing a ritual with the teeth to summon… something to create the Rot.
But try as I might, I can’t find out what these teeth are from, or what they are ultimately trying to summon. I don’t think this is over just yet…
You enter the first chamber to see a number of floating, burning figures, and apparently what was left of the villagers who entered the tomb before you has been ‘recruited’ into their service.
Oooh, Sun Demons. Now I’ve never encountered these before, though I have read manuals on how to fight them.
They are extremely accurate, so prevent damage if you can. Try and consume any Light Elements they create!
Great work! After all the battles I’ve seen you take part in, I’ll be able to write my own tactical manual some day.
There is no sign of the Savvas, so we’ll just have to take down the Demons first.
Beware, the Elements have been strengthened here and these Demons could have extra powers!
The Demons are destroyed, and the villagers of Rockfall begin to venture back out of their homes.
Have they got… Giant Snakes?
Certainly looks like it - watch out, those things can jump!
Ah, here we are, the cause of the problem: blasted Vermling Shamans. They can curse your whole party and heal their allies, if you can, take them down fast!
You reach the village and see Vermlings, armed with bows and arrows, commanding animals.
The main area around the trade route is now clear, although many Vermlings have retreated into deeper parts of the forest.
That looks like the last of the Artillery there. Destroy that, mop up the stragglers, and we should be able to leave without too much trouble.
You just HAD to jinx it, didn’t you?
Well, I guess a Cultist presence makes sense in a town built by magicians.
Why do the Cultists always work with people trying to kill us?
Because we aren’t the ones planning a magical world domination?
Yeah… I suppose that makes sense. Watch out for those Demons!
Well, this feels awfully familiar…
It does, but this force is much smaller than the stockpile at Millpond.
Let’s just hope they aren’t hiding anything nasty… like hidden taxes.
Destroy the Militia presence here, but be careful. There’s probably more in store than hidden taxes.
A weight lifts from the air as the last Cultist falls, but the stench of Harrower lingers.
With the battle over, you notice that Militia and Cultist bodies are not the only ones among the dead.
It looks like the Harrowers killed anyone that wouldn’t join them. I’ll bet these people weren’t even asked nicely!
We can not allow The Council of Shadow to kill any more people. We need to move now
At the Start of each round All Elements are set to Inert
The combination of demonic influence and necromancy has nullified all other magic in the area.
All Elements will be set to null at the end of every turn, so you won’t be able to rely on your more powerful magic in this fight!
As the last enemy is destroyed, you see the rot begin to withdraw, and your magic fires back to life.
I’d hope that’s the last we’ll see of the Night Demons, but I know that won’t be the case.
The Harrowers have grouped up with some Savvas here - you’ll have to be extra careful.
There’s something so… deliciously wrong about this whole situation. It’s just like committing tax fraud.
Yes, I can see the irony. You’ll have to fight alongside the bandits today!
Wait… how do you know what committing tax fraud is like?
Oh I’m, er, imagining of course.
The bandits stare at you as the last Militia soldier falls. They seem to have accepted you, for now.
Well, they have agreed to join our cause for revenge. Good work, we have our army.
We just need to get them something sharp to wave about so we can stop this Council doing the thing it’s doing.
Ah, Cultists. They may look relatively harmless at first glance, but you need to eliminate them as soon as possible as they have the ability to raise the undead.
That said, if mortally wounded they can die in the process!
Also, be aware that due to the powerful energies they are invoking, they sometimes have a tendency to explode when killed... so depending on how volatile they are looking, maybe stand back?
This branch of the Cult is no more, but they are still active in other parts of the realm. This won't be the last you’ll see of them!
At the Start of each round the Dark Element is set to Strong and the Light Element is set to Inert
Dark Power has always been said to warp around this area of the forest. It entirely blots out the power of Light too. Use that to your advantage!
The cultists are driven away from the manor, which is now safe again. You are unsure whether this is a good thing or not.
You’re almost to the seaport, and… wait, what’s this?
The Council will make all in this realm more powerful, and you will not stop them!
Looks like the Council have convinced more Savvas to join them. You’ll have to deal with them too.
Damn! It looks like this Council of Shadows knew you would come... They work faster than my town council does though, I’ll give them that.
Fortunately this garrison doesn’t look too big, you should be able to retake the seaport yourselves.
As the last defender falls, silence falls too, and the port workers slowly appear from their hiding spots.
I don’t like how organised this Militia is… It almost feels as though Keyport is at war.
Thankfully, the townspeople are happy to support us in our attack. We can finally put an end to this Council and their violence.
You reach a clearing in the forest which contains the entrance to a cave. There are pools or lava and rubble dotted everywhere, you’ll need to mind your step!
With the Demons dead, the route to Silverwick should be clear again.
A motley group of Vermlings and Inox burst out of the undergrowth, and you can hear more in the distance. Prepare for a large attack!
This is a rag-tag bunch of enemies. Although there are a lot of them, survive for long enough and they’ll likely lose heart.
As another enemy falls, the remaining adversaries turn tail and flee, their morale broken. You consider giving chase, but the forest is too dense and getting lost is a definite possibility.
Kill All Enemy Savvas
As expected, there is a welcoming party for you as you enter the tower.
Your meddling must come to an end. The Savvas are the master race and will not be polluted by others living here.
It looks as if more of the doors in this tower are blocked off by pressure plates. You’ll need to be smart to work your way through it.
With the Savvas killed, the Demons return to their own realm.
Ah, Night Demons. That would explain the powerful Dark presence.
As long as they aren’t Stone Golems, I’m quite happy.
Night Demons and Stone Golems? I don’t think the Council is strong enough to command both!
I think we may have spoken too soon.
Just kill it. I don’t want to look at it
Once it’s dead, prepare yourselves. The doors to the keep are on the other side of this room!
I expected the Council of Shadow to be a little more… impressive?
You have stood in the way of our gifts long enough, vermin. Your interference ends here.
You must make sure it is their interference that ends here, not ours!
At the Start of each round the Dark Element is set to Strong and the Light Element is set to Inert
Both groups should clear a way to the keep; you’re going to need all your strength to defeat the Council.
You’d think such a strong Council would have stronger walls on their hideout…
They did drain the Light out of this place, though. Be careful: Light is Null here, and Dark is Strong.
Now the Council are dead, you notice the scattered documents around their keep.
It seems from these documents that the Council believed controlling the population would have caused less wars.
You mean these stinking clouds actually thought they were helping?
The temperature in here is even lower than outside!
Frost Demons! They must be the cause of the Blizzard. You need to destroy them!
It seems a family of bears and some hounds have taken shelter, and they are not happy to see you!
If we are stuck here for any time, we’ll need to deal with these creatures and anything else in the rest of the network of caves.
The last Frost Demon falls and the temperature of the cave instantly rises to simply ‘cold’.
As expected, crystals lie scattered in the rear part of the cave. It seems the Savvas were expecting you to follow on this route.
Deep Terrors too?
Watch out for… whatever it is they do!
How did the smell get WORSE!?
It seems like some kind of... Rot blocking the sewage - hopefully killing these creatures will clear it.
Well, this is nothing like the paintings.
Are those… Black Imps?
They look like living sewage!
With the creatures dead, the Rot shrivels away and the sewage begins to flow properly again. In the rot’s place, spoiled spring water seeps through cracks in the sewer walls.
I think the source of this rot runs deeper. Have a wash, and we’ll investigate further.
Whatever this rot is, I’m not going anywhere near a sewer again.
All enemies have Poison added to their Attacks
These dogs look diseased. Be aware they have POISON on all their attacks.
I’m pretty sure that if you can survive long enough, they’ll turn tail and run.
Unable to break your resolve, the remaining hounds slink into the shadows and leave the tomb, scattering into the desert beyond.
Poisonous Hounds are even worse than normal Hounds... why don’t people just own a cat like I do?
As expected, out of the bushes stomp some very angry-looking Inox. You try to communicate with them, but to no avail. They prepare to attack.
It seems some of my less cultured cousins are going to mess with your day. Treat Inox as big angry humans - they aren’t too difficult to take down, unless they bring their Shaman along.
With the tribe defeated, your path from the forest is no longer barred. You continue to the Barren Coast.
That looks like the same Rot we found in Sweetwater, but it doesn’t appear to be the source.
It stinks the same. Do you think these creatures travel through the Rot?
Maybe… but they are definitely connected. Finish clearing the reservoir, and we’ll investigate further.
Well, there’s no doubt that these reservoirs are contaminated too.
I thought Oozes were just tall tales made up by drunken idiots, wrong again!
The Rot’s source is likely further inside. Push through, and watch the Oozes - they spread fast.
With the Rot cleared, the stench of stale water dominates. The reservoir stays dirty.
A southern river feeds this reservoir. It passes by the Inox settlement of Kailej, so we’ll head in that direction.
Well, this is new to me... Undead with flaming bows?
It looks as if their arrow heads may be explosive. Try and split up if possible!
It seems they return to the dust like any other Undead. Now, let’s see what the archaeologists can reward us with!
The Vermlings have made a simple camp here, and the Oasis is littered with their rubbish. As you step into view, they grab their weapons and attack.
With the last Vermling dead, the Oasis is a safe place for travellers once more.
You certainly expected to find Cultists down here, of course in the garb of the Umbran League. What you didn’t expect were Night Demons!
It seems they are not content with raising the dead, but are now in collusion with Demons. They must be stopped!
Peace returns to the Dome after its most recent battle for decades is now over.
Lose if both Elite Hounds die
All animals are permanently Strengthened.
In the first cavern, you find the Mayor’s Hounds locked in cages and quickly free them, using the commands he taught you to ensure they don’t attack.
Just then, Bandits come in from another Cavern.
‘Who are you lot? Oh bugger, they’ve let those Hounds free! Quick, get them!’
Bandits and other animals come into the cavern. It looks like you’ll have to fight your way out.
All the animals here seem to be acting strangely. I think they’ve been injected with something. You better look after those Hounds too - if they don’t make it, the Mayor isn’t going to be happy!
It seems the Bandits were trying out a strange elemental magic on these animals, that’s why they were all Strengthened.
Better take the Mayor’s Hounds back and get out of here.
Scientists eh? I’d never mess with necromancy.
Because you don’t understand magic and are terrified of the undead?
Well, that, and there isn’t a great return on investment. Also, some of the corpses end up looking like a particularly unpleasant uncle I used to have.
With the Undead returned to peace, you climb the stairs to the top of the tower to explain to the Quatryl the error of his ways.
You climb down into the temple. Wind howls down the corridors and there is a bitter chill in the air.
More Demons. Also the door looks... locked?
I believe it’s an ancient Savvas security system. You’ll need to stand on all pressure pads in a room to open the next door.
Okay. Let’s clear out all the rooms and see what the Savvas wanted here.
The Temple is quiet once more, and you take your time looking around for clues.
Oh dear, you have awoken some Living Spirits, the souls of those who died suddenly and unhappily.
Isn’t all death unhappy?
… Spirits have a resistance to damage, so you'll find attacks with Pierce more effective. They also fly, so the Traps won't help!
As the sun rises, the undead fall to the ground and you leave the tomb and its terrors. You then pile up stones over the entrance, so that no one else awakens the restless dead.
What are Lurkers doing so far from the sea? Is nowhere safe!?
Lurkers are a dangerous and intelligent race… there must be a reason they are going to such lengths for these teeth.
There is no Rot here. What has drawn the Black Imps?
Maybe the teeth are important to the Imps?
Hmm, possibly. Regroup as quickly as you can: there’s no telling what followed the imps here...
As the last Lurker falls into the sand, an uneasy peace falls over the camp.
Violent Lurkers this far from the ocean’s depths are a bad sign. We must make haste to the Inox.
What about the nomads? They might have some mone- I mean, information?
That is true, but it would be a detour. I’d have to consider it further.
What the… Bandits working with Vermlings? These guys are going to have a lot of ranged attacks, best get up close and personal!
As the last bow falls to the ground, you patch your wounds and head off towards the pub.
Entering this cavern, you find the source of the music: a group of Imps generating the magical melody. Although the children are not here, you feel that they are nearby.
The cave leads down to a room protected by stone guardians and the air is infused with magic that should boost any Healing abilities.
Beware, those Golems have a healing aura on them! You’ll have to work hard to take them down.
With the last enemy dead, the music abruptly stops and you immediately hear the sounds of voices from the rear of the cavern.
After a short search, you detect an illusion placed on the area hiding an entranceway to an antechamber with a group of children inside.
They seem scared, but unharmed. You lead them back to the town
Drakes, this far east? Something must have made them leave the mountains!
Beware their poison, and the walking ones have a ferocious set of bites. Attack from range if you can.
I expect the harsh winter has driven them to forage further for food. Expect more Drake encounters across the realm.
This is a Bounty mission, which means to succeed you will need to kill a certain number of enemies.
The good news is that the whole battle will take place in this single clearing, the bad news is that enemies will keep spawning until you kill enough.
Good Job, I don’t think they’ll be coming back in a hurry!
You raise your eyes and see Imps in the clearing, and something you’ve not encountered before.
Wind Demons! I should have guessed, with that strange weather...
It seems someone is trying to stop you reaching Wayward. You’ll need to drive them away.
As you kill another Wind Demon, the storm picks up again and you cover your eyes. When it abates, you are once again alone.
Entering the crypt, you are greeted by a magical voice. ‘Welcome, Heroes of Wildspire, time has come again for you to prove your worth.’
‘Prepare you swords and spells, and defeat the minions’.
You step into the next room, and are faced with Stone Golems and reanimated skeletons.
With all of the creatures dead, the voice speaks out once more: ‘Well done, your have proven yourselves again. The might of Wildspire shall never fail!’

You sniff the air as you descend the familiar stone steps, and the stale smell of death and decay fills you with anger - an anger focused on yourself. You remember the first time you stepped down into these depths and smelled this odor. It was your first job after you arrived in Gloomhaven. And you remember being scared by it.

You would never have dreamed of exposing your fear to your companions. They were depending on you to lead the charge into your bandit foes. When you’re this big, no one expects you to feel fear, but sometimes it’s inevitable.

Still, your reaction to this place has haunted you ever since. When you began to hear rumors about a powerful weapon hidden in the depths of the Black Barrow, you jumped at the opportunity to return and face its dangers alone.

You are stronger now - more seasoned. Walking down these steps no longer fills you with dread, only excitement. You hope that more pathetic bandits have made this place their home since the last time you charged through these dark halls.
You reach the bottom of the steps and bash open the door. You are not disappointed.
Despite your numerous wounds, you press on into the final room. Everything is exactly as you remember - smug bandits and animated bones.
You shouldn't have come...' An archer begins to talk, but you silence her with a dismissive wave of your hand. These fools aren’t important enough to waste your time with speeches.
You limp toward the stairs at the back of the room and can’t help but let out a bellowing laugh. You are unstoppable, a force to be reckoned with.

Trailing blood, you make your way into the lower catacombs, looking for the telltale clues of your quarry. Perhaps it is luck, or perhaps the rest of the bandits were terrified of your laughter, but either way, you find the sword and leave without further incident.

Welcome, guildmaster! I'm the Guild Trainer, and I'm here to guide you through setting up your own mercenary Guild. Let's start with you guiding the Brute through this first tutorial.
Before we get to the action, you’ll want to acquaint yourself with how to adjust your view of the battlefield, so let’s go over the camera controls.

W A S D - Pan camera Q E - Rotate camera left/right +/- or Mousewheel Up/Down - Zoom camera in/out You can also rotate the camera by dragging your mouse with the middle mouse button held. Try them out now and press Continue when you're ready to move on.

In Gloomhaven, you control a party of mercenaries, each equipped with a deck of Ability Cards. These cards are how your mercenaries will explore dungeons, fight enemies and loot treasure. At the beginning of each round, the first thing to do is to select two cards for each mercenary to use on their turn.

In this tutorial, the Brute has just three cards at his disposal, as you can see highlighted on the left: Grab and Go, Trample and Provoking Roar. Provoking Roar is greyed out to indicate that it is currently discarded (for the sake of the tutorial), so for now let's just select the two cards the Brute has available.

See the how the '?' next to the Brute's portrait at the top of the screen has changed into a number? This shows his initiative. The number next to the first card you select determines the character's initiative for the round. The lower the number, the earlier in the round the character will act.
Since there are no other characters visible right now, it will immediately be the Brute's turn anyhow.
Now it is the Brute's turn, time to choose some actions. Each half of a card represents an action, comprised of one or more abilities.

You get to use two actions per turn, and you can pick any of the four card halves on the left to use as your first action - but note that you must then use the opposite side of the other card for your second.
For example, here you can choose either the top half of Trample and the bottom half of Grab and Go...
...or the bottom half of Trample and the top half of Grab and Go.

There's nothing for the Brute to do in this room, so you'll want to proceed through the door to see what lies beyond with a Move ability. Grab and Go's bottom half lets the Brute move four hexes, which is enough to get through the door. Let's use that!

This room contains your first enemy, a Bandit Guard! Like player characters, monsters also select actions for their turn - let's find out what this Bandit is planning to do this round by hovering over his portrait.

Whilst hovered, you can see the Bandit's intentions this round: he plans to Move and Attack! Whereas player characters get two actions per turn, monsters only get one - albeit often with multiple abilities within.

Notice how this Bandit has a lower initiative than the Brute, and would have acted before the Brute this round had he been visible. As it is currently the Brute’s turn however, you'll get to finish his turn before the Bandit can act.
Let's get the Brute close enough to use the Attack on Trample's top half as the second action for the turn!
Now that you've finished using Grab and Go for the turn, it is discarded and no longer usable until you return it to hand via resting - more on that later. For now, time to Attack!

Whenever you Attack, an attack modifier is drawn from your character's modifier deck and that value is applied to your Attack. In this case you can see above the Bandit Guard that a +0 modifier was drawn, so your Attack still just deals its base value of 3 damage.
For this tutorial, we will only have +0 modifiers in effect to keep things simple. We'll explore the other attack modifiers later!

Now it is the Bandit’s turn. As we saw on his card earlier, he intends to Move and then perform a melee Attack for 3 damage. However, as he is already within melee range of the Brute, he will simply forgo moving and get straight to the Attack.
Ouch! While monsters always take damage directly to their hit points, whenever a player character is damaged, you are presented with three options:

Firstly, you can simply take the damage to your character's hit point total. However, if this is reduced to 0, this character is exhausted, which means they can no longer act in this scenario. If all of your mercenaries are exhausted, you will lose the scenario!
Secondly, you can choose to burn two discarded ability cards instead of receiving the damage. If you burn a card it can no longer be recovered by resting.
However, if you were to burn two of Brute's cards here, he would not have enough cards left for the following turn, and thus would be exhausted!
Finally, you can choose to burn one available card. This option is greyed out as all of the Brute's cards are currently discarded.

It is usually wise to take the damage over burning cards if possible, lest you run out of cards to finish the scenario with! For now, let's opt to just take the three damage, as the Brute has enough health to survive.
The Bandit’s turn is now over. As he was the last character to act, it is the end of the round, and a new round begins.

During ability card selection, if you have at least two discarded cards then you may perform a Long or Short Rest to recover some of them. All of the Brute's ability cards are currently discarded (Long Rest doesn't count as a card) and as such he will have to rest to continue.

Short Rest will burn one of your discarded cards at random, losing it for the rest of the scenario, but will recover all other discarded cards before continuing your turn as normal - so you can recover cards to use immediately in this very turn.

Long Rest takes up the whole turn, and is used instead of selecting two ability cards, giving the character an initiative of 99. However, you not only get to choose which card to burn instead of it being at random, but the character will perform a "Heal 2" action and refresh all item cards!
Choosing to Long Rest here would be certain death if the Bandit draws an attack card for the round, as the Brute has neither health nor cards to spare, so let's choose to Short Rest.

Grab and Go has been randomly selected as the card to burn. Once per short rest you can opt to redraw the random card to burn at the cost of one damage, but with the Brute only on 1 health, this isn’t an option!
You can see Grab and Go is now dark red to indicate it is burned and no longer usable in the current scenario.
In exchange, Trample and Provoking Roar have been returned to hand and are available to use again!

Both the Brute and the Bandit are near-death, so it is crucial to go as early as possible in the round to get the first attack! Remember, the first card you choose determines the Brute’s initiative, so let's choose Provoking Roar to maximise the chance Brute is up first with a low initiative of 10.

Now that we are in the same room as the Bandit, we can see that enemies draw their ability cards each round after the player(s), so you won't know what they'll be doing or what their initiatives will be until this point in each round. It appears the Bandit was planning to once again use a Move and an Attack, but because you chose to act quickly with an initiative of 10, he won't have those active until after the Brute's turn due to a slower initiative of 50! Let's get him!

Got him! Do you see that gold on the floor that the Bandit left behind? To pick it up, you need to use a Loot ability. One important rule of Gloomhaven to bear in mind is that you don’t automatically loot treasure - if you want it, you'll have to pick it up before the scenario ends!

Loot abilities can appear on ability cards, but often the easiest way to collect it is to end your turn on a hex that contains a gold pile. So, let's move the Brute onto the gold before the end of his turn with his remaining action!
But, wait... look at Provoking Roar. It doesn't have a Move ability on the bottom half's action, so how can the Brute reach the gold?

This is where default actions come in handy! To the left and right of the central initiative value are two small default action buttons. These allow the character to perform a melee Attack for 2 instead of the top action or a default Move of 2 instead of the bottom action.
Since you only need to Move one hex for the Brute to reach the gold, we can skip the remaining movement using the skip button below.
Great work! Not only did you vanquish the, err... lone Bandit Guard, you’ve even managed to pick up a few pieces of gold!
With the basics covered, it's now time to introduce you to some slightly more dangerous scenarios...
Two Hex Obstacle

Wayward

The starting location for many an adventure, Wayward is the stopping off point for Merchants travelling between Gloomhaven and Demonsgate. Much of the rare spices and silks from the Valrath empire passes through here, giving the town an exotic feel.
Wildspire
Rising above the treeline is a ramshackle tower made of old logs and branches. It seems to be a Vermling construction. Who knows what they have to trade?
